bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, August 10, 1939

div1.p: Hench plans to visit Havana in March 1940. He would like to see and photograph the actual site of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, August 10, 1939
div1.opener:
Yellow fever.
August 10, 1939
Mr. John J. Moran
c/o Cia Sunoco de Cuba, S. A.
Avenida Menocal Nos. 455-57
Habana, Cuba
My dear Mr. Moran:
div1.p:
I was interested indeed to read the nice article about
you in the Saturday Evening Post of August 5. I still am not satisfied
that your story has been told properly. There is only one person to
tell it and that is you, and I am still planning to help in this matter
as I have written.

I am hoping to take my vacation in March in Palm
Beach, and run over to Havana for three or four days. I am wondering
if you are planning to be there in February or March, and whether it
would be convenient for me to see you. I should appreciate it very
much if you could go over part of the story with me, clearing up some
minor discrepancies and perhaps showing me the actual site of the
camp and some of the experiments. I notice that Mr. Furnas suggests
that photographs where the camp was might not be permitted, as it is
so near the present home of Colonel Batista. It would be most interest-
ing, indeed, to have photographs of the old site of the camp, and if
you think this could not be possible without special permission, I should
like to start the ball rolling to get such permission, perhaps by writing
the American Ambassador, and going through the proper channels. I am
sure Colonel Batista would have no objection if he knew why these photo-
graphs were being taken.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
